item.title: By: Pinchos Chalk
item.dc:creator: Pinchos Chalk
item.description:
Honey (being very sweet) is never brought as a korban to Hashem. We are commanded not to include honey in the ketores notwithstanding the fact that if it was included then 'ein kol adam yachol la'amod mipnei reichah'.
The idea of the gates of light of the chanuka lights seems to be more of a perception that you have to and can fight (as the Macabees did) to perceive rather than being representative of a pervasive sweet light that fills life.
According to both Beis Shammai and Beis Hillel - 'noach lo le'adam shelo nivra mishenivra, ve'achshav shenivra yephashpesh be'maasav...' Life itself is not an inherent accomplishment.
item.content:encoded:
Honey (being very sweet) is never brought as a korban to Hashem. We are commanded not to include honey in the ketores notwithstanding the fact that if it was included then ‘ein kol adam yachol la’amod mipnei reichah’.

The idea of the gates of light of the chanuka lights seems to be more of a perception that you have to and can fight (as the Macabees did) to perceive rather than being representative of a pervasive sweet light that fills life.

According to both Beis Shammai and Beis Hillel – ‘noach lo le’adam shelo nivra mishenivra, ve’achshav shenivra yephashpesh be’maasav…’ Life itself is not an inherent accomplishment.
